metadata.Title: CVE-2020-25632 on Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (xenial) - medium.
metadata.Description:
A flaw was found in grub2 in versions prior to 2.06. The rmmod implementation allows the unloading of a module used as a dependency without checking if any other dependent module is still loaded leading to a use-after-free scenario. This could allow arbitrary code to be executed or a bypass of Secure Boot protections. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity as well as system availability. Chris Coulson discovered that the rmmod command in GRUB 2 contained a use-after-free vulnerability. A local attacker could use this to execute arbitrary code and bypass UEFI Secure Boot restrictions.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2020-25632` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

grub-efi-amd64-signed - 1.164
grub-efi-arm64-signed - 1.164
No subscription required

grub-efi-amd64 - 2.04-1ubuntu42
grub-efi-amd64-bin - 2.04-1ubuntu42
grub-efi-arm64 - 2.04-1ubuntu42
grub-efi-arm64-bin - 2.04-1ubuntu42
No subscription required

notes.Note: alexmurray> CVE title: "grub2: use-after-free in rmmod command" sbeattie> grub2-unsigned will contain fixes and supersede grub2, which will contain only BIOS grub bits.

criterions.comment: grub2: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support').
grub2-signed package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '1.164').
grub2-unsigned package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '2.04-1ubuntu42').
